properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall continues tonight into Wednesday. Snow will continue with additional snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 locally 15 cm possible tonight through Wednesday morning. Strong northerly winds gusting near 60 km/h are possible tonight, particularly near Lake Huron or Georgian Bay. This snowfall is a result of a strengthening low pressure system expected to move through eastern Ontario into Quebec tonight into Wednesday. Precipitation associated with this low pressure system is expected to move east of the area by Wednesday afternoon. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-02T20:44:57-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-02T06:41:57-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1775615251.2020
Area: Hanover - Dundalk - Southern Grey County, Shelburne - Mansfield - Northern Dufferin County, Orangeville - Grand Valley - Southern Dufferin County
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A major winter storm continues. The very moist Pacific frontal system will remain stalled over the coastal passes tonight and Wednesday. Consequently, heavy precipitation will continue. The heavy snow is forecast to change over to heavy rain tonight as warmer air pushes in. Rainfall amounts of near 50 mm are expected by Wednesday evening. ### Road closures are possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-02T20:31:46-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-02T04:32:46-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0511027550.2020
Area: Haines Road - Haines Junction to Pleasant Camp, South Klondike Highway - Carcross to White Pass

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and local blowing snow continues tonight. An additional 5 cm of snow is possible, mainly between Watford and London. Hazards: up to 5 cm of additional snow Blowing snow Wind gusts to 70 km/h Impacts: Poor visibility in quickly accumulating snow and blowing snow Poor road conditions Worst impacts expected between Watford and London Timing: Continuing now through early Wednesday morning 20-30 cm of snow has been reported at London Airport and by weather spotters in Parkhill and Strathroy so far through this event. The current band of snow is expected to move out of the region in a couple hours. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-02T12:59:25-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-02T06:09:25-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3821444047.2020

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall continues tonight. Snow, heavy at times, and blowing snow will continue tonight. Additional snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 centimetres are possible before the snow weakens Wednesday morning. Falling snow, along with wind gusts up to 70 km/h, will allow for blowing snow to occur and significantly affect visibilities tonight and early Wednesday morning. This snowfall is the result of a low pressure system that has moved into southern Quebec this evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
